en-US: several people talking at once distract a listener .

zh-CN: （6）字幕测试集。
en-US: ( 6 ) subtitle test data .

zh-CN: ﻿我演讲的题目是《展翅的鸟儿与太空望远镜》。
en-US: my talk is " flapping birds and space telescopes . "

zh-CN: 你会觉得他们相互之间没有联系，但我希望在18分钟以后，你能看到一些关联。
en-US: and you would think that should have nothing to do with one another , but i hope by the end of these 18 minutes , you'll see a little bit of a relation .

zh-CN: 这与折纸有关。
en-US: it ties to origami .

zh-CN: 下面我就开始了。
en-US: so let me start .

zh-CN: 什么是折纸？
en-US: what is origami ?

zh-CN: 很多人以为他们知道折纸是什么。
en-US: most people think they know what origami is .

zh-CN: 它是这样的：展翅的鸟儿、玩具、东西南北之类的东西。
en-US: it's this : flapping birds , toys , cootie catchers , that sort of thing .

zh-CN: 折纸术以前是这样的。
en-US: and that is what origami used to be .

zh-CN: 但它已经改变了。
en-US: but it's become something else .

zh-CN: 它已经成为了一种艺术形式，一种雕塑形式。
en-US: it's become an art form , a form of sculpture .

zh-CN: 共同的主题——折纸术的本质——是折叠，也是我们如何创造形态的。
en-US: the common theme -- what makes it origami -- is folding , is how we create the form .

zh-CN: 你们知道，这非常古老。
en-US: you know , it's very old .

zh-CN: 这是1797年的一幅画。
en-US: this is a plate from 1797 .

zh-CN: 上面是这些妇女们玩纸玩具的场景。
en-US: it shows these women playing with these toys .

zh-CN: 如果你靠近点看，它是这种形状的，叫做鹤。
en-US: if you look close , it's this shape , called a crane .

zh-CN: 每个日本孩子都学折纸鹤。
en-US: every japanese kid learns how to fold that crane .

zh-CN: 所以这种艺术已经存在了数百年，你可能会想如果某种东西已经存在了这么久——如此有限制性，只能折叠——那么所有能做出的东西应该在很久以前就做出来了。
en-US: so this art has been around for hundreds of years , and you would think something that's been around that long -- so restrictive , folding only - - everything that could done has been done a long time ago .

zh-CN: 实际情况也许会是如此。
en-US: and that might have been the case .

zh-CN: 但在20世纪，一位名为吉泽的日本折纸艺术家出现了，他创造出了数万种全新的设计。
en-US: but in the 20 th century , a japanese folder named yoshizawa came along , and he created tens of thousands of new designs .

zh-CN: 更重要的是，他创造了一种语言——一种我们可以交流的方式，一种由点、破折号和箭头构成的代码。
en-US: but even more importantly , he created a language - - a way we could communicate , a code of dots , dashes and arrows .

zh-CN: 联系到苏珊·布莱克摩尔的演讲，我们现在有了一种通过传承与选择传递信息的方法，我们也知道它的走向。
en-US: harkening back to susan blackmore's talk , we now have a means of transmitting information with heredity and selection , and we know where that leads .

zh-CN: 而它在折纸术中产生的是这样的东西。
en-US: and where it has led in origami is to things like this .

zh-CN: 这是一个折纸作品：一张纸，没有裁剪，只有折叠，数百次折叠。
en-US: this is an origami figure : one sheet , no cuts , folding only , hundreds of folds .

zh-CN: 而这也是折纸，它显示出我们在现代世界中的已经走到哪了。
en-US: this too is origami , and this shows where we've gone in the modern world .

zh-CN: 你可以做出犄角，鹿角——如果你靠近看，偶蹄。
en-US: you can get horns , antlers -- even if you look close , cloven hooves .

zh-CN: 这就引出一个问题：什么发生了改变？
en-US: and it raises a question : what changed ?

zh-CN: 发生变化的是一种你在艺术中可能不曾期待的东西，那就是数学。
en-US: and what changed is something you might not have expected in an art , which is math .

zh-CN: 也就是说，人们将数学原理应用到艺术中，来发现潜在的规律。
en-US: that is , people applied mathematical principles to the art , to discover the underlying laws .

zh-CN: 这就形成了一种强大的工具。
en-US: and that leads to a very powerful tool .

zh-CN: 在众多领域提高生产力的秘密——包括在折纸术中——是让死去的人为你工作。
en-US: the secret to productivity in so many fields -- and in origami -- is letting dead people do your work for you .

zh-CN: 因为你所能做的是将你的问题转变成一个其他人已经解决的问题，并运用他们的解决方法。
en-US: because what you can do is take your problem and turn it into a problem that someone else has solved , and use their solutions .

zh-CN: 而我想要告诉你们，我们是如何在折纸术中做到这一点的。
en-US: and i want to tell you how we did that in origami .

zh-CN: 折纸术是围绕折痕图进行的。
en-US: origami revolves around crease patterns .

zh-CN: 这个折痕图就是一个折纸造型的设计图
en-US: the crease pattern shown here is the underlying blueprint for an origami figure .

zh-CN: 设计图可不能随便画。
en-US: and you can't just draw them arbitrarily .

zh-CN: 它们必须遵循4个简单的规则。
en-US: they have to obey four simple laws .

zh-CN: 它们非常简单，并且很好理解。
en-US: and they're very simple , easy to understand .

zh-CN: 第一个规则是双可着色性。
en-US: the first law is two-colorability .

zh-CN: 你可以用两种颜色填充你想画的的折痕图而相同的颜色不会相邻。
en-US: you can color any crease pattern with just two colors without ever having the same color meeting .

zh-CN: 在任何顶点的折叠方向--凸折法的数量，凹折法的数量--之间总是相差两下。
en-US: the directions of the folds at any vertex -- the number of mountain folds , the number of valley folds -- always differs by two .

zh-CN: 多折或少折两下。
en-US: two more or two less .

zh-CN: 就这么简单。
en-US: nothing else .

zh-CN: 如果观察折痕周围的角，你会发现在数围成一圈的角时，所有列为偶数的角加起来是一条直线。
en-US: if you look at the angles around the fold , you find that if you number the angles in a circle , all the even-numbered angles add up to a straight line .

zh-CN: 所有列为奇数的角加起来是一个直线。
en-US: all the odd-numbered angles add up to a straight line .

zh-CN: 接下来，如果观察这些纸是怎么叠加起来的，你会发现不论怎样叠加褶层和纸片，纸片永远不能穿透褶层。
en-US: and if you look at how the layers stack , you'll find that no matter how you stack folds and sheets , a sheet can never penetrate a fold .

zh-CN: 这就是四则简单的规则。
en-US: so that's four simple laws .

zh-CN: 在折纸艺术中这就是全部。
en-US: that's all you need in origami .

zh-CN: 所有的折纸都源于这些。
en-US: all of origami comes from that .

zh-CN: 现在你觉得：“那些复杂的工艺能是从四则简单的规则中衍生出来的吗？”
en-US: and you ' d think , " can four simple laws give rise to that kind of complexity ? "

zh-CN: 但是，事实上，量子力学的法则可以在一张餐巾纸上写出来。而它们可以支配所有的化学，甚至生活和历史的全部。
en-US: but indeed , the laws of quantum mechanics can be written down on a napkin , and yet they govern all of chemistry , all of life , all of history .

zh-CN: 如果遵循这些规则，我们能做出令人吃惊的事。
en-US: if we obey these laws , we can do amazing things .

zh-CN: 所以折纸时，在遵循这些规则的情况下，我们可以做出简单的样式--比如这个重复的折叠样式，叫做纹理--虽然这样单独看起来很普通。
en-US: so in origami , to obey these laws , we can take simple patterns -- like this repeating pattern of folds , called textures -- and by itself it's nothing .

zh-CN: 但如果我们遵守折纸的规则，我们能把这些样式加入另一种折法，这种折法本身非常非常的简单。但当我们把它加进来，会得到很不一样的东西。
en-US: but if we follow the laws of origami , we can put these patterns into another fold that itself might be something very , very simple , but when we put it together , we get something a little different .

zh-CN: 这条鱼有400片鱼鳞，同样，它是一张没被剪过的正方形纸张。
en-US: this fish , 400 scales -- again , it is one uncut square , only folding .

zh-CN: 如果你不想折400片鱼鳞，你可以退而求其次，做些简单的折叠得到一只乌龟的背壳或脚趾。
en-US: and if you don't want to fold 400 scales , you can back off and just do a few things , and add plates to the back of a turtle , or toes .

zh-CN: 或者可以提升成为一面拥有50颗星星和13条横条的旗子（美国国旗）。
en-US: or you can ramp up and go up to 50 stars on a flag , with 13 stripes .

zh-CN: 如果你想做些疯狂的事情，这有一条有1000片鳞片的响尾蛇。
en-US: and if you want to go really crazy , 1,000 scales on a rattlesnake .

zh-CN: 这个作品展示在楼下，所以你们有机会可以看看。
en-US: and this guy's on display downstairs , so take a look if you get a chance .

zh-CN: 在折纸艺术中，最有用的方法和我们怎样构造生物的一部分有关。
en-US: the most powerful tools in origami have related to how we get parts of creatures .

zh-CN: 我可以用一个简单的等式来解释。
en-US: and i can put it in this simple equation .

zh-CN: 我们产生了一个想法，把它与张纸片结合，就能得到一个折纸作品。
en-US: we take an idea , combine it with a square , and you get an origami figure .

zh-CN: 重要的是这些符号代表什么。
en-US: what matters is what we mean by those symbols .

zh-CN: 你们可能会问：“真的能做到那么具体吗？
en-US: and you might say , " can you really be that specific ?

zh-CN: 我是说一只鹿角虫有两个点状的嘴，和触角。你真的能做到具体到细节吗？”
en-US: i mean , a stag beetle -- it's got two points for jaws , it's got antennae . can you be that specific in the detail ? "

zh-CN: 是的，真的可以。
en-US: and yeah , you really can .

zh-CN: 那该怎么做呢？
en-US: so how do we do that ?

zh-CN: 我们把它分成几个小步骤。
en-US: well , we break it down into a few smaller steps .

zh-CN: 为此，让我来展开这个等式。
en-US: so let me stretch out that equation .

zh-CN: 我先从我的构思开始，使它抽象化。
en-US: i start with my idea. i abstract it .

zh-CN: 什么是最抽象的形式呢？线条画。
en-US: what's the most abstract form ? it's a stick figure .

zh-CN: 然后从这个线条画，我得用某种方式得到折叠的式样，并且包括想要表现对象的所有部分。
en-US: and from that stick figure , i somehow have to get to a folded shape that has a part for every bit of the subject .

zh-CN: 一片三角形折叠对应一条腿。
en-US: a flap for every leg .

zh-CN: 然后，我们称这个折叠的式样为基础。你可以使它的腿变细，使其弯曲，你可以把它做成成品。
en-US: and then once i have that folded shape that we call the base , you can make the legs narrower , you can bend them , you can turn it into the finished shape .

zh-CN: 第一步：很简单。
en-US: now the first step : pretty easy .

zh-CN: 做出一个构思，画一幅线条图。
en-US: take an idea , draw a stick figure .

zh-CN: 最后一步也不是很难，但中间的一步--把抽象的描绘变为折叠的式样--这很难。
en-US: the last step is not so hard , but that middle step -- going from the abstract description to the folded shape -- that's hard .

zh-CN: 但就是在这，数学理论让我们翻越难关。
en-US: but that's the place where the mathematical ideas can get us over the hump .

zh-CN: 我要向你们展示怎样做，这样离开这里后，你们可以叠出些东西。
en-US: and i'm going to show you all how to do that so you can go out of here and fold something .

zh-CN: 但我们要先从小的开始。
en-US: but we're going to start small .

zh-CN: 这个基础有很多片状物。
en-US: this base has a lot of flaps in it .

zh-CN: 我们要学习怎样做一个片状物。
en-US: we're going to learn how to make one flap .

zh-CN: 你会怎样叠一个片状物呢？
en-US: how would you make a single flap ?

zh-CN: 拿一张正方形的纸，把它对折再对折，直到它变得又长又细，然后这个的尾部就是一个片状物。
en-US: take a square. fold it in half , fold it in half , fold it again , until it gets long and narrow , and then we'll say at the end of that , that's a flap .

zh-CN: 我能用它做一条腿，一只手臂，和所有相似的东西。
en-US: i could use that for a leg , an arm , anything like that .

zh-CN: 在片状物中是什么样的纸呢？
en-US: what paper went into that flap ?

zh-CN: 如果把它展开去看它的折痕图，你们可以看到在纸片的左上角的形状就是构成片状物的纸。
en-US: well , if i unfold it and go back to the crease pattern , you can see that the upper left corner of that shape is the paper that went into the flap .

zh-CN: 所以那就是一个片状物，和所有剩下的纸。
en-US: so that's the flap , and all the rest of the paper's left over .

zh-CN: 我可以用剩下的部分做点别的。
en-US: i can use it for something else .

zh-CN: 也有另外的做片状物的方法。
en-US: well , there's other ways of making a flap .

zh-CN: 也有不同形状的片状物。
en-US: there's other dimensions for flaps .

zh-CN: 如果把片状物叠得更细一些，所用的纸会更少。
en-US: if i make the flaps skinnier , i can use a bit less paper .

zh-CN: 如果把片状物尽可能的叠细，就能只用片状物所需的最少的纸。
en-US: if i make the flap as skinny as possible , i get to the limit of the minimum amount of paper needed .

zh-CN: 就像你们所看到的，只需要纸上四分之一个圆就可以作出一个片状物。
en-US: and you can see there , it needs a quarter-circle of paper to make a flap .

zh-CN: 还有别的做片状物的方法。
en-US: there's other ways of making flaps .

zh-CN: 如果把片状物放在纸片边上，就需要一个半圆的纸。
en-US: if i put the flap on the edge , it uses a half circle of paper .

zh-CN: 如果把片状物放在纸片的中心，就需要一整圆。
en-US: and if i make the flap from the middle , it uses a full circle .

zh-CN: 就是说不论怎样叠，片状物是由纸上圆形区域的一部分做成的。
en-US: so no matter how i make a flap , it needs some part of a circular region of paper .

zh-CN: 现在让我们来提升到新的水平。
en-US: so now we're ready to scale up .

zh-CN: 如果要叠一个有很多片状物的东西该怎么办呢？
en-US: what if i want to make something that has a lot of flaps ?

zh-CN: 我需要什么？
en-US: what do i need ?

zh-CN: 我需要很多的圆。
en-US: i need a lot of circles .

zh-CN: 在二十世纪九十年代，折纸艺术家发现了这些规则，并了解到我们可以通过组合圆形来叠出任意复杂的形状。
en-US: and in the 1990 s , origami artists discovered these principles and realized we could make arbitrarily complicated figures just by packing circles .

zh-CN: 这就是那些死去的人能帮到我们的地方。
en-US: and here's where the dead people start to help us out .

zh-CN: 因为很多人都研究过组合圆形的问题。
en-US: because lots of people have studied the problem of packing circles .

zh-CN: 我可以依赖那些有关圆的组合和排列的大量的数学与艺术的历史。
en-US: i can rely on that vast history of mathematicians and artists looking at disc packings and arrangements .

zh-CN: 然后我可以用这些式样来制造折纸的形状。
en-US: and i can use those patterns now to create origami shapes .

zh-CN: 我们可以依据这些规则来组合圆形，依据更多的规矩我们可以用线条来装饰圆。
en-US: so we figured out these rules whereby you pack circles , you decorate the patterns of circles with lines according to more rules .

zh-CN: 这就有了折叠线。
en-US: that gives you the folds .

zh-CN: 沿这些线折叠就可以得到大体形状。
en-US: those folds fold into a base .

zh-CN: 你们就做出了大体的形状。
en-US: you shape the base .

zh-CN: 你们得到一个折叠的形状，在这里，是一只蟑螂。
en-US: you get a folded shape -- in this case , a cockroach .

zh-CN: 而且它非常的简单。
en-US: and it's so simple .

zh-CN: 因为它很简单，电脑就可以把它做出来。
en-US: it's so simple that a computer could do it .

zh-CN: 你们可能问“那能有多简单呢？”
en-US: and you say , " well , you know , how simple is that ? "

zh-CN: 但是要用电脑，你们需要用最基本的方法来描述一件事物。而这里我们可以做到。
en-US: but computers , you need to be able to describe things in very basic terms , and with this we could .

zh-CN: 所以我在很多年前写了一个电脑程序，叫做TreeMaker(造树者），你们可以在我的网页上下载它。
en-US: so i wrote a computer program a bunch of years ago called treemaker , and you can download it from my website .

zh-CN: 它是免费的。
en-US: it's free .

zh-CN: 它可以在大部分的操作系统里面运行，甚至在Windows里。
en-US: it runs on all the major platforms -- even windows .

zh-CN: 然后你们就可以自己画一个线条图，这个程序会根据线条图计算折痕。
en-US: and you just draw a stick figure , and it calculates the crease pattern .

zh-CN: 这个程序可以排列圆形，计算折痕，还有如果你们用刚才我展示的线条图，你们可以看出它是一只有角的鹿，你们就可以得到这个折痕图。
en-US: it does the circle packing , calculates the crease pattern , and if you use that stick figure that i just showed , which you can kind of tell -- it's a deer , it's got antlers -- you'll get this crease pattern .

zh-CN: 用这个折痕图，折叠有虚线的地方，你们就能得到一个基础，然后再用你们想用的方法叠出一只鹿。
en-US: and if you take this crease pattern , you fold on the dotted lines , you'll get a base that you can then shape into a deer , with exactly the crease pattern that you wanted .

zh-CN: 如果你们想要一只不同种的鹿，而不是白尾鹿，你们可以改变圆形的排列，然后得到一只麋鹿。
en-US: and if you want a different deer , not a white-tailed deer , you change the packing , and you can do an elk .

zh-CN: 或是一只驼鹿。
en-US: or you could do a moose .

zh-CN: 或是其它任何一种鹿。
en-US: or really , any other kind of deer .

zh-CN: 这些技术改革了这门艺术。
en-US: these techniques revolutionized this art .

zh-CN: 我们发现我们可以叠出昆虫，或是相近的蜘蛛，有脚的东西，有脚和翅膀的东西，和有脚和触角的东西。
en-US: we found we could do insects , spiders , which are close -- things with legs , things with legs and wings , things with legs and antennae .

zh-CN: 如果用一张没剪过的正方形纸叠一只螳螂还不够有趣的话，你们可以用一张没剪过的正方形纸叠两只螳螂。
en-US: and if folding a single praying mantis from a single uncut square wasn't interesting enough , then you could do two praying mantises from a single uncut square .

zh-CN: 她在吃他。
en-US: she's eating him .

zh-CN: 我称之为“点心时间”。
en-US: i call it " snack time. "

zh-CN: 你们能做的不只是昆虫。
en-US: and you can do more than just insects .

zh-CN: 你们可以把它做到有细节，像指头和爪子。
en-US: this -- you can put details : toes and claws .

zh-CN: 一只有爪子的北美洲灰熊。
en-US: a grizzly bear has claws .

zh-CN: 和这只有脚趾的树蛙。
en-US: this tree frog has toes .

zh-CN: 实际上，在折纸艺术中有很多人把指头加入到他们的模型中。
en-US: actually , lots of people in origami now put toes into their models .

zh-CN: 指头变成了折纸艺术的文化基因。
en-US: toes have become an origami meme .

zh-CN: 因为每个人都在做。
en-US: because everyone's doing it .

zh-CN: 你可以做出多种的物体。
en-US: you can make multiple subjects .

zh-CN: 像这里有一些音乐家。
en-US: so these are a couple of instrumentalists .

zh-CN: 一个正方形做出的吉他手。一个正方形做出的贝斯手。
en-US: the guitar player from a single square , the bass player from a single square .

zh-CN: 如果你说，“好吧，但吉他和贝斯不够帅。
en-US: and if you say , " well , but the guitar , bass -- that's not so hot .

zh-CN: 做些更复杂的乐器吧。”
en-US: do a little more complicated instrument. "

zh-CN: 那你可以做一架风琴。
en-US: well , then you could do an organ .

zh-CN: 所以在这个世界里我们能做出所需要的创造。
en-US: and what this has allowed is the creation of origami-on-demand .

zh-CN: 如果现在有人说，我想要这个这个还有这个。你就可以精确的把它们叠出来。
en-US: so now people can say , i want exactly this and this and this , and you can go out and fold it .

zh-CN: 有时可以做纯艺术。有时可以做些商品卖钱。
en-US: and sometimes you create high art , and sometimes you pay the bills by doing some commercial work .

zh-CN: 但是我想给你们看一些例子。
en-US: but i want to show you some examples .

zh-CN: 除了车子，你们将看到的所有东西都是折纸。
en-US: everything you'll see here , except the car , is origami .

zh-CN: 就是想展示给你们这些真实的折纸。
en-US: just to show you , this really was folded paper .

zh-CN: 电脑使所有的东西动起来。但是这些折纸全都是货真价实的。
en-US: computers made things move , but these were all real folded objects that we made .

zh-CN: 我们不只可以在视觉上运用到折纸艺术，它实际上在现实世界中也很有用。
en-US: and we can use this not just for visuals , but it turns out to be useful even in the real world .

zh-CN: 令人惊奇的，折纸和从折纸中发展出来的结构可以在医药学，科学，太空，身体和电子产品等等上得到应用。
en-US: surprisingly , origami , and the structures that we ' ve developed in origami , turn out to have applications in medicine , in science , in space , in the body , consumer electronics and more .

zh-CN: 我想展示一些例子。
en-US: and i want to show you some of these examples .

zh-CN: 在最早的应用中有这样一个样式，折纸样式，由日本的工程师KoryoMiura发明的。
en-US: one of the earliest was this pattern : this folded pattern , studied by koryo miura , a japanese engineer .

zh-CN: 他研究这个折纸样式，然后发现可以折出很紧凑的包装，有很简单的开口和闭合结构。
en-US: he studied a folding pattern , and realized this could fold down into an extremely compact package that had a very simple opening and closing structure .

zh-CN: 他应用这个技术设计了这个太阳能电池板。
en-US: and he used it to design this solar array .

zh-CN: 这是一个艺术家的表演，但它在1995应用到了一架日本望远镜。
en-US: it's an artist's rendition , but it flew in a japanese telescope in 1995 .

zh-CN: 现在在詹姆斯韦伯太空望远镜中只有一点点的折纸艺术，但它十分之简单。
en-US: now , there is actually a little origami in the james webb space telescope , but it's very simple .

zh-CN: 这架进入太空的望远镜在两处展开。
en-US: the telescope -- going up in space , it unfolds in two places .

zh-CN: 它在第三个处折叠。
en-US: it folds in thirds .

zh-CN: 它是一个很简单的式样，你都不会把它称作折纸。
en-US: it's a very simple pattern -- you wouldn't even call that origami .

zh-CN: 这些科学家的确不用跟折纸艺术家讨论。
en-US: they certainly didn't need to talk to origami artists .

zh-CN: 但当你要更深入的研究时，折纸术是必需的。
en-US: but if you want to go higher and go larger than this , then you might need some origami .

zh-CN: 劳伦斯利物穆尔国家实验室的工程师们有一个关于一个更大的望远镜的构想。
en-US: engineers at lawrence livermore national lab had an idea for a telescope much larger .

zh-CN: 他们称之为“镜片”。
en-US: they called it " the eyeglass. "

zh-CN: 这个设计需要同步轨道，高于地面26000英里，和直径100米的镜片。
en-US: the design called for geosynchronous orbit , 26,000 miles up , 100-meter diameter lens .

zh-CN: 所以镜片有一个橄榄球场那么大。
en-US: so , imagine a lens the size of a football field .

zh-CN: 有两类人对这个望远镜有兴趣：想要观察太空的行星学家，和其他想要观察地球的人。
en-US: there were two groups of people who were interested in this : planetary scientists who want to look up , and then other people who wanted to look down .

zh-CN: 不论你想观察什么，该怎么上太空呢？
en-US: whether you look up or look down , how do you get it up in space ?

zh-CN: 你需要一个火箭。
en-US: you ' ve got to get it up there in a rocket .

zh-CN: 而且火箭一般都很小。
en-US: and rockets are small .

zh-CN: 所以你需要把望远镜做的小一些。
en-US: so you have to make it smaller .

zh-CN: 怎么把一大片玻璃变小呢？
en-US: how do you make a large sheet of glass smaller ?

zh-CN: 唯一的办法就是折叠。
en-US: well , about the only way is to fold it up somehow .

zh-CN: 所以你要做这样的事，这一个小型的模型。
en-US: so you have to do something like this -- this was a small model .

zh-CN: 对于镜片，你把板面分区然后加上弯曲。
en-US: for the lens , you divide up the panels , you add flexures .

zh-CN: 但是这个样式不能把100米的东西变成几米。
en-US: but this pattern's not going to work to get something 100 meters down to a few meters .

zh-CN: 所以利物穆尔的工程师们，想要利用那些死去的人的成果，或是活着的折纸艺术家的成果。工程师们说“看看有没有别人在做这类事。”
en-US: so the livermore engineers , wanting to make use of the work of dead people , or perhaps live origamists , said , " let's see if someone else is doing this sort of thing. "

zh-CN: 所以他们研究折纸圈。我们和折纸艺术家取得联系，而我开始和他们一起工作。
en-US: so they looked into the origami community , we got in touch with them , and i started working with them .

zh-CN: 我们一起开发了一个可以应用到任意大小，但可以允许所有的平面环或圆盘折成一个整洁紧凑的圆柱体的样式。
en-US: and we developed a pattern together that scales to arbitrarily large size , but that allows any flat ring or disc to fold down into a very neat , compact cylinder .

zh-CN: 他们在第一代的望远镜中采用了这个样式。而第一代并不是100米而是5米。
en-US: and they adopted that for their first generation , which was not 100 meters -- it was a five-meter .

zh-CN: 但是这个5米的望远镜有0.25英里的焦距。
en-US: but this is a five-meter telescope -- has about a quarter-mile focal length .

zh-CN: 而且在它的测试范围内效果很好。它也的确被叠成了一小捆。
en-US: and it works perfectly on its test range , and it indeed folds up into a neat little bundle .

zh-CN: 现在，还有别的折纸术应用到太空中。
en-US: now , there is other origami in space .

zh-CN: 在这里所被解决的问题是做出了一个在旅途中很小但在目的地很大的薄片状的物体。
en-US: the problem that's being solved here is something that needs to be big and sheet-like at its destination , but needs to be small for the journey .

zh-CN: 这个可以作用于当你想进入太空，或是想进入人的身体时。
en-US: and that works whether you ' re going into space , or whether you ' re just going into a body .

zh-CN: 这个例子就是进入人身体的。
en-US: and this example is the latter .

zh-CN: 这是由牛津大学的钟游发明的心脏手术支架。
en-US: this is a heart stent developed by zhong you at oxford university .

zh-CN: 它在到达目的地时会打开被堵塞的动脉血管。但在旅途中它需要变得很小才能通过你的血管。
en-US: it holds open a blocked artery when it gets to its destination , but it needs to be much smaller for the trip there , through your blood vessels .

zh-CN: 这个支架运用一种折纸术被叠小。我们称这个模型为水弹模型。
en-US: and this stent folds down using an origami pattern , based on a model called the water-bomb base .

zh-CN: 安全气囊的设计师也遇到了同样的把大薄片塞进小空间里的问题。
en-US: airbag designers also have the problem of getting flat sheets into a small space .

zh-CN: 而且他们都是通过仿真技术来做设计。
en-US: and they want to do their design by simulation .

zh-CN: 所以他们需要在电脑里研究出怎样使安全气囊变平。
en-US: so they need to figure out how , in a computer , to flatten an airbag .

zh-CN: 我们所开发出的叠昆虫的算法在这里变成了在仿真技术中解决安全气囊问题的方法。
en-US: and the algorithms that we developed to do insects turned out to be the solution for airbags to do their simulation .

zh-CN: 所以设计师可以做一个这个的模仿。
en-US: and so they can do a simulation like this .

zh-CN: 那些就是折纸的折痕，现在你们所看到的就是正在放气的安全气囊并且大家可以知道这方法管不管用。
en-US: those are the origami creases forming , and now you can see the airbag inflate and find out : does it work ?

zh-CN: 这个例子实际上可以推导出一个十分有趣的构想。
en-US: and that leads to a really interesting idea .

zh-CN: 你们知道，这些发明设计都是从哪来么？
en-US: you know , where did these things come from ?

zh-CN: 这个心脏手术支架是从大家小学就学到的纸气球中衍生来的。
en-US: well , the heart stent came from that little blow-up box that you might have learned in elementary school .

zh-CN: 它们有着相同的构造，称之为“水弹模型”。
en-US: it's the same pattern , called " the water-bomb base. "

zh-CN: 那个使安全气囊变平的算法是从那些实际上只是发明出来用来叠昆虫，也就是有腿的东西，的数学理论。
en-US: the airbag-flattening algorithm came from all the developments of circle packing and the mathematical theory that was really developed just to create insects -- things with legs .

zh-CN: 其实呢，这样的事经常发生在数学和科学里面。
en-US: the thing is , that this often happens in math and science .

zh-CN: 当你运用数学，解决你纯粹为了美学价值或是创造美而想解决的问题时，实际上结果反过来在现实世界中也可以应用。
en-US: when you get math involved , problems that you solve for aesthetic value only , or to create something beautiful , turn around and turn out to have an application in the real world .

zh-CN: 而且即使听上去很奇怪，折纸术有一天可能会救人一命。
en-US: and as weird and surprising as it may sound , origami may someday even save a life .

zh-CN: 让我们从日夜开始。
en-US: let's start with day and night .

zh-CN: 生命的进化在光明与黑暗中进行，光明，然后是黑暗。
en-US: life evolved under conditions of light and darkness , light and then darkness .

zh-CN: 因此植物和动物都进化出自己的内部时钟，这使得他们能适应光线的改变。
en-US: and so plants and animals developed their own internal clocks so that they would be ready for these changes in light .

zh-CN: 这是化学时钟，每个已知的多细胞生物体内都有这种时钟，部分单细胞生物也有这种时钟。
en-US: these are chemical clocks , and they're found in every known being that has two or more cells and in some that only have one cell .

zh-CN: 举个例子。
en-US: i'll give you an example .

zh-CN: 如果你从海滩上抓一只鲎，把它空运到大陆的另一端，接着把它放入一个倾斜的笼子里，在它数千里外家乡的海岸涨潮的时候，它会爬到笼子的高处。而退潮时它又会退回笼子底部。
en-US: if you take a horseshoe crab off the beach , and you fly it all the way across the continent , and you drop it into a sloped cage , it will scramble up the floor of the cage as the tide is rising on its home shores , and it'll skitter down again right as the water is receding thousands of miles away .

zh-CN: 这种行为它会重复数个星期，直到它渐渐失去这种判断能力。
en-US: it'll do this for weeks , until it kind of gradually loses the plot .

zh-CN: 这非常不可思议，但这不是什么灵异或是超自然现象；原因很简单，这些鲎拥有能与周围环境相协调的内部周期。
en-US: and it's incredible to watch , but there's nothing psychic or paranormal going on ; it's simply that these crabs have internal cycles that correspond , usually , with what's going on around it .

zh-CN: 我们也有这种能力。
en-US: so , we have this ability as well .

zh-CN: 就人类而言，我们称之为生物钟。
en-US: and in humans , we call it the body clock .

zh-CN: 当你拿走某个人的手表，把他关进一个深入地下的地下堡垒关上几个月，你就能更清楚地观察到生物钟的作用。
en-US: you can see this most clearly when you take away someone's watch and you shut them into a bunker , deep underground , for a couple of months .

zh-CN: 实际上有志愿者做过这个实验，他们从洞里出来时对他们在洞里的时间有点混乱。
en-US: people actually volunteer for this , and they usually come out kind of raving about their productive time in the hole .

zh-CN: 不管这些志愿者显得多不合逻辑，有一件事可以确认。
en-US: so , no matter how atypical these subjects would have to be , they all show the same thing .

zh-CN: 他们每天都比之前晚起一点--大约15分钟左右--在这几星期内他们的生物钟就像这样不断向后推延。
en-US: they get up just a little bit later every day -- say 15 minutes or so -- and they kind of drift all the way around the clock like this over the course of the weeks .

zh-CN: 而且，就这样，我们知道他们是用自己的生物钟做到这点的，而不是用某种方式感知外面的日光。
en-US: and so , in this way , we know that they are working on their own internal clocks , rather than somehow sensing the day outside .

zh-CN: 那么好的，我们有生物钟，并且它对我们的生活极其重要。
en-US: so fine , we have a body clock , and it turns out that it's incredibly important in our lives .

zh-CN: 它也是文化的巨大推动力，我认为这是在我们的行为中最被低估的一种力量。
en-US: it's a huge driver for culture , and i think that it's the most underrated force on our behavior .

zh-CN: 我们人类是从赤道附近进化而来的一个物种，因此我们能非常好的适应12小时的白昼和12小时的黑夜。
en-US: we evolved as a species near the equator , and so we're very well-equipped to deal with 12 hours of daylight and 12 hours of darkness .

zh-CN: 不过当然，我们现在已经遍布全球的每个角落，在我居住的加拿大北极地区，夏天是极昼，而冬天则是极夜。
en-US: but of course , we've spread to every corner of the globe , and in arctic canada , where i live , we have perpetual daylight in summer and 24 hours of darkness in winter .

zh-CN: 因此传统上北部原住民文化是高度季节性的。
en-US: so the culture , the northern aboriginal culture , traditionally has been highly seasonal .

zh-CN: 在冬天，睡眠时间很长。
en-US: in winter , there's a lot of sleeping going on .

zh-CN: 人们在室内享受家庭生活。
en-US: you enjoy your family life inside .

zh-CN: 而在夏天则是疯狂的狩猎及很长时间的劳作，非常活跃。
en-US: and in summer , it's almost manic hunting and working activity very long hours , very active .

zh-CN: 那么，我们的自然节奏应该是什么样的呢？
en-US: so , what would our natural rhythm look like ?

zh-CN: 我们的理想中的睡眠模式应是什么样的呢？
en-US: what would our sleeping patterns be in the sort of ideal sense ?

zh-CN: 嗯，事实表明，当生活在完全没有任何人工光源的环境中时，人们会每晚睡两次。
en-US: well , it turns out that , when people are living without any sort of artificial light at all , they sleep twice every night .

zh-CN: 人们在晚上8点左右睡觉。
en-US: they go to bed around 8:00 pm .

zh-CN: 直到午夜，接着再次入睡，大约从凌晨2点直到日出。
en-US: until midnight and then again , they sleep from about 2:00 am until sunrise .

zh-CN: 在这两次睡眠之间，有几个小时在床上安静的沉思。
en-US: and in-between , they have a couple of hours of sort of meditative quiet in bed .

zh-CN: 在这段时间内，催乳素产生这样的情况在现代社会不会出现。
en-US: and during this time , there's a surge of prolactin , the likes of which a modern day never sees .

zh-CN: 这些研究中的人们在白天觉得很清醒，他们意识到正在经历生命中的第一次真正的失眠。
en-US: the people in these studies report feeling so awake during the daytime , that they realize they're experiencing true wakefulness for the first time in their lives .

zh-CN: 那么，转到现代社会。
en-US: so , cut to the modern day .

zh-CN: 我们的文化中充满时差，全球旅行，24小时营业，倒班工作。
en-US: we're living in a culture of jet lag , global travel , 24-hour business , shift work .

zh-CN: 你知道，我们现代人的这种生活方式有它的优点，但我想我们应该明白所付出的代价。
en-US: and , you know , our modern ways of doing things have their advantages , but i believe we should understand the costs .

zh-CN: 海洋是一个非常复杂的事物。
en-US: it can be a very complicated thing , the ocean .

zh-CN: 人类的健康也是一件非常复杂的事情。
en-US: and it can be a very complicated thing , what human health is .

zh-CN: 将两者统一起来看起来是一件艰巨的任务。
en-US: and bringing those two together might seem a very daunting task .

zh-CN: 但我想要试图去说明的是即使是如此复杂的情况，也存在一些我认为简单的话题，一些如果我们能理解，就很容易向前发展的话题。
en-US: but what i'm going to try to say is that even in that complexity , there's some simple themes that i think , if we understand , we can really move forward .

zh-CN: 这些简单的话题确实不是有关那复杂的科学有了怎样的发展，而是一些我们都恰好知道的事情。
en-US: and those simple themes aren't really themes about the complex science of what's going on , but things that we all pretty well know .

zh-CN: 接下来我就来说一个。
en-US: and i'm going to start with this one .

zh-CN: 如果老妈不高兴了，大家都别想开心。
en-US: if momma ain't happy , ain't nobody happy .

zh-CN: 我们都知道，不是吗？我们都经历过。
en-US: we know that , right ? we've experienced that .

zh-CN: 接下来如果我们能理解这一点从这里出发，可以得出下一步的，那就是如果海洋不高兴了大家也都别想开心。
en-US: and if we just take that and we build from there , then we can go to the next step , which is that if the ocean ain't happy , ain't nobody happy .

zh-CN: 这就是我演讲的主题。
en-US: that's the theme of my talk .

zh-CN: 我们正在通过许多不同的方法惹怒海洋。
en-US: and we're making the ocean pretty unhappy in a lot of different ways .

zh-CN: 这是1932年在坎纳里鲁夫拍的一副照片
en-US: this is a shot of cannery row in 1932 .

zh-CN: 那时的坎纳里鲁夫，有着西海岸最大的工业化罐头工厂。
en-US: cannery row , at the time , had the biggest industrial canning operation on the west coast .

zh-CN: 我们堆积了大量的污染物在空气中和水中
en-US: we piled enormous amounts of pollution into the air and into the water .

zh-CN: 我所工作的霍普金的海洋研究站的罗尔夫·博林教授，在二十世纪40年代指出，“海湾入口里浮沫所散发的臭气特别难闻那里有含铅的黑涂料。
en-US: rolf bolin , who was a professor at the hopkin's marine station where i work , wrote in the 1940 s that , " the fumes from the scum floating on the inlets of the bay were so bad they turned lead-based paints black. "

zh-CN: 工作在罐头厂的人们每天都只能待在这样的气味之中。
en-US: people working in these canneries could barely stay there all day because of the smell .

zh-CN: 然而你知道他们说什么吗？
en-US: but you know what they came out saying ?

zh-CN: 他们说：“你知道你闻到的是什么吗？
en-US: they say , " you know what you smell ?

zh-CN: 你闻到的是钱的气味。”
en-US: you smell money . "

zh-CN: 污染来自于社区的金钱利益。
en-US: that pollution was money to that community .

zh-CN: 那些人们和污染生活在一起并把污染吸入了它们的皮肤和身体因为他们需要钱。
en-US: and those people dealt with the pollution and absorbed it into their skin and into their bodies because they needed the money .

zh-CN: 让海洋不高兴，人们也特别不高兴，并且人类还不再健康。
en-US: we made the ocean unhappy ; we made people very unhappy , and we made them unhealthy .

zh-CN: 海洋的健康和人类健康之间的联系确实就像另一组谚语说的那样。
en-US: the connection between ocean health and human health is actually based upon another couple simple adages .

zh-CN: 我觉得这么说：“抓了小鱼，害死鲸鱼”
en-US: and i want to call that " pinch a minnow , hurt a whale. "

zh-CN: 海洋生物的食物链……
en-US: the pyramid of ocean life ...

zh-CN: 现在……当一位生态学者看待海洋的时候——我承认——我们用一种十分不同的方式来看待海洋，比起普通人，我们看待海洋时发现的不同之处更多。
en-US: now ... when an ecologist looks at the ocean -- i have to tell you -- we look at the ocean in a very different way , and we see different things than when a regular person looks at the ocean .

zh-CN: 因为当生态学家看待海洋的时候，会看到其中的相互联系。
en-US: because when an ecologist looks at the ocean , we see all those interconnections .

zh-CN: 我们看食物链的下层，浮游生物这种小东西，还会看这些小动物们是如何成为位于金字塔中部动物们的食物的，然后就这样一直向上走到这幅图的顶部。
en-US: we see the base of the food chain , the plankton the small things , and we see how those animals are food to animals in the middle of the pyramid , and on so up this diagram .

zh-CN: 这种生命的流动从最底部流向最顶部，是生态学家们关注的。
en-US: and that flow , that flow of life , from the very base up to the very top , is the flow that ecologists see .

zh-CN: 并且这就是我们努力去保护的当我们说：“救救海洋，给海洋治治病吧。”
en-US: and that's what we're trying to preserve when we say , " save the ocean . heal the ocean . "

zh-CN: 说的就是这金字塔。
en-US: it's that pyramid .

zh-CN: 那么为什么这与人类的健康有关系呢？
en-US: now why does that matter for human health ?

zh-CN: 因为，当我们把一些本不该在食物链底部存在的东西塞进了金字塔食物链之后，就出现了很可怕的事情。
en-US: because when we jam things in the bottom of that pyramid that shouldn't be there , some very frightening things happen .

zh-CN: 一些由我们制造的污染物，像是PCB分子（多氯联苯，一种致癌物质）是不能被我们的身体吸收的。
en-US: pollutants , some pollutants have been created by us , molecules like pcbs that can't be broken down by our bodies .

zh-CN: 它们进入到食物链金字塔的底部，并不断向上，经过食物链，到达肉食动物和顶端肉食动物这里。
en-US: and they go in the base of that pyramid , and they drift up , they're passed up that way , on to predators and on to the top predators .

zh-CN: 这样的话，就堆积起来了。
en-US: and in so doing , they accumulate .

zh-CN: 然后，为了能彻底了解这个问题，我想邀请大家做个小游戏
en-US: now , to bring that home , i thought i'd invent a little game .

zh-CN: 我们并不是真的要玩，只是在这里想一下就好。
en-US: we don't really have to play it. we can just think about it here .

zh-CN: 这是个保丽龙发泡胶和巧克力的游戏。
en-US: it's the styrofoam and chocolate game .

zh-CN: 想象一下当我们登上这艘船，我们都得到了两个保丽龙的花生。
en-US: imagine that when we got on this boat , we were all given two styrofoam peanuts .

zh-CN: 除了把它们放在兜里，你也做不了什么其他的。
en-US: can't do much with them but put them in your pocket .

zh-CN: 因为规则是：每一次你请别人喝一杯的时候，除了要给别人酒之外，也要把你的保丽龙花生给别人。
en-US: because the rules are : every time you offer somebody a drink , you give them the drink , and you give them your styrofoam peanuts too .

zh-CN: 接下来发生的事情就是保丽龙花生会开始在我们的团体里流通。
en-US: what'll happen is that the styrofoam peanuts will start moving through our society here .

zh-CN: 并且它们会集中在最吝啬的醉鬼身上
en-US: and they will accumulate in the drunkest stingiest people .

zh-CN: 这个游戏里面的机制让人们什么也做不了除了得到越来越大的一堆无法消化的保丽龙花生。
en-US: there's no mechanism in this game for them to go anywhere but into a bigger and bigger pile of indigestible styrofoam peanuts .

zh-CN: 这就是和PDB分子（对二氯苯，化学合成药剂，致癌）在食物链中的堆积一样。
en-US: and that's exactly what happens with pdbs in this food pyramid .

zh-CN: 它们富集在食物链的顶部。
en-US: they accumulate into the top of it .

zh-CN: 然后假设不用保丽龙花生，我们用这些可爱的巧克力来替代它们。
en-US: now suppose instead of styrofoam peanuts , we take these lovely little chocolates that we get and we had those instead .

zh-CN: 嗯，我们之中的一些人会把巧克力吃了而不给别人。
en-US: well , some of us would be eating those chocolates instead of passing them around .

zh-CN: 这样就不会产生堆积，它们只会在人群中流通但不会堆积在人群里。
en-US: and instead of accumulating , they will just pass into our group here and not accumulate in any one group .

zh-CN: 因为巧克力可以被我们吸收。
en-US: because they're absorbed by us .

zh-CN: 这与PCB分子是不同的，可以说，就像ω-3脂肪酸一样天然，我们希望海洋食物链里有这些东西。
en-US: and that's the difference between a pcb and , say , something natural like an omega-3 , something we want out of the marine food chain .

zh-CN: PCB的富集。
en-US: pcbs accumulate .

zh-CN: 很不幸，有许多这种例子
en-US: we have great examples of that , unfortunately .

zh-CN: PCB堆积在海豚体内就发生在萨拉索塔湾，得克萨斯州，北卡罗来纳州。
en-US: pcbs accumulate in dolphins in sarasota bay , in texas , in north carolina .

zh-CN: PCB分子进入了食物链。
en-US: they get into the food chain .

zh-CN: 海豚吃了小鱼小鱼从浮游生物那里得到了PCB分子，这些脂溶性的PCB分子就富集在了海豚体内。
en-US: the dolphins eat the fish that have pcbs from the plankton , and those pcbs , being fat-soluble , accumulate in these dolphins .

zh-CN: 现在，一只海豚，海豚母亲，或者是任何的海豚只有一种方法排出PCB分子。
en-US: now , a dolphin , mother dolphin , any dolphin -- there's only one way that a pcb can get out of a dolphin .

zh-CN: 是什么呢？
en-US: and what's that ?

zh-CN: 通过母乳。
en-US: in mother's milk .

zh-CN: 这是一张萨拉索塔湾海豚体内PCB含量的图表。
en-US: here's a diagram of the pcb load of dolphins in sarasota bay .

zh-CN: 成年雄性体内的含量巨大。
en-US: adult males , a huge load .

zh-CN: 幼年海豚体内也有很大含量。
en-US: juveniles , a huge load .

zh-CN: 雌性在第一次哺乳期之后含量稍低。
en-US: females after their first calf is already weaned , a lower load .

zh-CN: 雌性海豚并不想这样。
en-US: those females , they're not trying to .

zh-CN: 它们将PCB分子通过乳汁里面的脂肪传递给了它们的后代。
en-US: those females are passing the pcbs in the fat of their own mother's milk into their offspring .

zh-CN: 而后代没有活下来。
en-US: and their offspring don't survive .

zh-CN: 这些海豚的死亡率，每只雌性海豚的第一胎，大约在60%到80％。
en-US: the death rate in these in these dolphins , for the first calf born of every female dolphin , is 60 to 80 percent .

zh-CN: 母亲们把污染物都输送给了第一胎后代。
en-US: these mothers pump their first offspring full of this pollutant .

zh-CN: 其中大部分都会死去。
en-US: and most of them die .

zh-CN: 现在，雌性海豚可以继续繁殖了，但这代价太大了污染物富集在这些动物体内——这要由第一胎后代的死来买单。
en-US: now , the mother then can go and reproduce , but what a terrible price to pay for the accumulation of this pollutant in these animals -- the death of the first born calf .

zh-CN: 原来，在海洋食物链里还有另外一个顶端捕食者
en-US: there's another top predator in the ocean , it turns out .

zh-CN: 显然，这个顶端捕食者就是我们。
en-US: that top predator , of course , is us .

zh-CN: 我们也吃肉来自于同样一些地方的肉。
en-US: and we also are eating meat that comes from some of these same places .

zh-CN: 这是鲸鱼肉我在东京一家食品店拍到的或者不是？
en-US: this is whale meat that i photographed in a grocery store in tokyo -- or is it ?

zh-CN: 实际上，我们做了几年的研究研究如何偷运一所分子生物实验室进东京用于遗传学的检验检验鲸鱼肉中去出的DNA样本并鉴定它们到底是什么。
en-US: in fact , what we did a few years ago was learn how to smuggle a molecular biology lab into tokyo and use it to genetically test the dna out of whale meat samples and identify what they really were .

zh-CN: 一部分鲸鱼肉样本确实是鲸鱼肉。
en-US: and some of those whale meat samples were whale meat .

zh-CN: 顺带一说，另一部分检验出不合规格。
en-US: some of them were illegal whale meat , by the way .

zh-CN: 这是另一个话题了。
en-US: that's another story .

zh-CN: 但是有一些就根本不是鲸鱼肉。
en-US: but some of them were not whale meat at all .

zh-CN: 即使有着鲸鱼肉的幌子，实际上这些是海豚肉。
en-US: even though they were labeled whale meat , they were dolphin meat .

zh-CN: 有一些是海豚肝脏。有一些是海豚的鳍。
en-US: some of them were dolphin liver . some of them were dolphin blubber .

zh-CN: 那些海豚肉都含巨量的PCB分子，二恶英（剧毒）和重金属。
en-US: and those dolphin parts had a huge load of pcbs , dioxins and heavy metals .

zh-CN: 这些有害物质都流入到食用这些肉的人身体内。
en-US: and that huge load was passing into the people that ate this meat .

zh-CN: 这证明许多海豚在世界上的鲸肉市场里都被当作肉食出售。
en-US: it turns out that a lot of dolphins are being sold as meat in the whale meat market around the world .

zh-CN: 对海豚来说这是一场悲剧。
en-US: that's a tragedy for those populations .

zh-CN: 但对食用它们的人类来说同样是一场悲剧因为他们并不知道这是有毒的肉。
en-US: but it's also a tragedy for the people eating them because they don't know that that's toxic meat .

zh-CN: 几年前的一天我们得出的这些数据。
en-US: we had these data a few years ago .

zh-CN: 我记得我坐在办公桌旁作为世界上唯一的人唯一知道在鲸鱼肉市场上卖的那些鲸鱼肉实际上是海豚肉,并且含毒的人。
en-US: i remember sitting at my desk being about the only person in the world who knew that whale meat being sold in these markets was really dolphin meat , and it was toxic .

zh-CN: 含有的毒素是有史以来环保局允许的2-3倍到400倍。
en-US: it had two-to-three-to-400 times the toxic loads ever allowed by the epa .

zh-CN: 并且我记得我坐在办公桌之前想：“嗯，我发现了这个，这是个伟大的科学发现。”
en-US: and i remember there sitting at my desk thinking , " well , i know this. this is a great scientific discovery. "

zh-CN: 但它如此可怕。
en-US: but it was so awful .

zh-CN: 在我科学生涯中，我第一次打破了科学的协议，就是做出数据并发布在科学杂志上，然后再谈论它们。
en-US: and for the very first time in my scientific career i broke scientific protocol , which is that you take the data and publish them in scientific journals , and then begin to talk about them .

zh-CN: 我们写了一封很客气的信给日本卫生部长并简单的指出并非对于我们是一个不可忍受的情况，而是对于日本人民。
en-US: we sent a very polite letter to the minister of health in japan and simply pointed out that this is an intolerable situation , not for us , but for the people of japan .

zh-CN: 因为需要哺乳的母亲们，有小孩的母亲们，应该买她们认为健康的东西，但这些东西实际上有毒。
en-US: because mothers who may be breastfeeding , who may have young children , would be buying something that they thought was healthy , but it was really toxic .

zh-CN: 这导致了日本一系列的其他运动。
en-US: that led to a whole series of other campaigns in japan .

zh-CN: 在这一点上，我真的非常骄傲的说，在日本买任何东西都很难这是标签贴错了，即使他们仍然在出售鲸肉，而我认为他们不该这么做。
en-US: and i'm really proud to say that at this point , it's very difficult to buy anything in japan that's labeled incorrectly , even though they're still selling whale meat , which i believe they shouldn't .

zh-CN: 但是至少标签帖对了你就不回再去买有毒的海豚肉。
en-US: but at least it's labeled correctly , and you ' re no longer going to be buying toxic dolphin meat instead .

zh-CN: 并不是只有日本才这样，而是在一些国家的自然食物链都这样在加拿大北部，在美国还有欧洲北部，海豹和鲸鱼的自然食物链导致了PCB分子的富集从世界上的各个地方聚集到妇女的身上。
en-US: it isn't just there that this happens , but in a natural diet of some communities in the canadian arctic and in the united states and in the european arctic , a natural diet of seals and whales leads to an accumulation of pcbs that have gathered up from all parts of the world and ended up in these women .

zh-CN: 这些妇女的乳汁含毒。
en-US: these women have toxic breast milk .

zh-CN: 她们不能用她们的乳汁来喂养她们的孩子们因为富集的毒素在她们的食物链之中，在她们世界中的一部分在海洋金字塔食物链里。
en-US: they cannot feed their offspring , their children , their breast milk because of the accumulation of these toxins in their food chain , in their part of the world's ocean pyramid .

zh-CN: 这说明她们的免疫系统已经受到危害。
en-US: that means their immune systems are compromised .

zh-CN: 这说明她们后代的生长发育也会受到危害。
en-US: it means that their children's development can be compromised .

zh-CN: 近十年世界上对这一问题的关注已经帮助这些妇女解决了这个问题，不是通过改变食物链结构，而是改变她们特有的饮食。
en-US: and the world's attention on this over the last decade has reduced the problem for these women , not by changing the pyramid , but by changing what they particularly eat out of it .

zh-CN: 我们已经让这些妇女脱离自然的食物链目的就是解决这个问题。
en-US: we've taken them out of their natural pyramid in order to solve this problem .

zh-CN: 对于这个特别尖锐的问题，这是个好办法，但它对解决金字塔食物链问题没什么帮助。
en-US: that's a good thing for this particular acute problem , but it does nothing to solve the pyramid problem .

zh-CN: 还有另一种方法打破金字塔食物链。
en-US: there's other ways of breaking the pyramid .

zh-CN: 如果我们在金字塔食物链底部塞入一些东西，食物链可以像下水道那样回堵上来。
en-US: the pyramid , if we jam things in the bottom , can get backed up like a sewer line that's clogged .

zh-CN: 如果我们在食物链底部加入营养物质、污水和化肥，那将影响整个食物链。
en-US: and if we jam nutrients , sewage , fertilizer in the base of that pyramid , it can back up all through it .

zh-CN: 下面用我们之前听过的例子结束这件事：赤潮，赤潮里有大量有毒藻类，漂浮在海洋之上的赤潮能造成精神受损。
en-US: and we end up with things we've heard about before : red tides for example , which are blooms of toxic algae floating through the oceans causing neurological damage .

zh-CN: 我们也可能会让海洋里的细菌，和病毒大量繁殖。
en-US: we can also get blooms of bacteria , blooms of viruses in the ocean .

zh-CN: 这里的两张照片都是红潮的这里面有一种弧菌，带有霍乱细菌。
en-US: these are two shots of a red tide coming on shore here and a bacteria in the genus vibrio , which includes the genus that has cholera in it .

zh-CN: 有多少人见过“海岸禁入”的标志呢？
en-US: how many people have seen a " beach closed " sign ?

zh-CN: 为什么会这样呢？
en-US: why does that happen ?

zh-CN: 因为我们把太多垃圾扔到了海洋食物链的底部这些细菌大量繁殖，并回溢到我们的海滩上。
en-US: it happens because we have jammed so much into the base of the natural ocean pyramid that these bacteria clog it up and overfill onto our beaches .

zh-CN: 一般困扰我们的都是污水。
en-US: often what jams us up is sewage .

zh-CN: 那么有多少人曾经去过州立公园或是国家公园呢？在那的门口曾经看到一块大标志上这样写着吗？“因垃圾太多充斥公园而关闭”
en-US: now how many of you have ever gone to a state park or a national park where you had a big sign at the front saying , " closed because human sewage is so far over this park that you can't use it " ?

zh-CN: 不常见吧？我们不能容忍这种事情。
en-US: not very often. we wouldn't tolerate that .

zh-CN: 我们不能容忍公园被垃圾堆满。
en-US: we wouldn't tolerate our parks being swamped by human sewage .

zh-CN: 但是在我们国家海岸却关闭了很多。
en-US: but beaches are closed a lot in our country .

zh-CN: 世界各地越来越多，越来越多的海岸关闭都是因为同样的原因。
en-US: they're closed more and more and more all around the world for the same reason .

zh-CN: 我相信这些我们也不应该容忍。
en-US: and i believe we shouldn't tolerate that either .

zh-CN: 这不只是清洁的问题。
en-US: it's not just a question of cleanliness .

zh-CN: 同时也是海洋有机物如何进入到人类疾病中的问题。
en-US: it's also a question of how those organisms then turn into human disease .

zh-CN: 那些弧菌和细菌确实可以感染人类。
en-US: these vibrios , these bacteria , can actually infect people .

zh-CN: 它们可以进入皮肤并造成皮肤感染。
en-US: they can go into your skin and create skin infections .

zh-CN: 这张图是来自美国国家气象局提议的海与人类健康法案，说明过去几年中，越来越多的人受到弧菌感染。
en-US: this is a graph from noaa's ocean and human health initiative , showing the rise of the infections by vibrio in people over the last few years .

zh-CN: 举例来说，冲浪的人十分了解这一情况。
en-US: surfers , for example , know this incredibly .

zh-CN: 如果你登录一些冲浪网站，实际上不光能看到海浪和天气如何，有一些冲浪者网站，还会有一些闪烁的警示。
en-US: and if you can see on some surfing sites , in fact , not only do you see what the waves are like or what the weather's like , but on some surf rider sites , you see a little flashing poo alert .

zh-CN: 这表示海边可能有大浪，但这对冲浪者来说是危险的因为他们会一直携带海洋中的细菌，即使是在冲浪之后的很多天，这些遗留物造成的感染也许要花很长时间去治疗。
en-US: that means that the beach might have great waves , but it's a dangerous place for surfers to be because they can carry with them , even after a great day of surfing , this legacy of an infection that might take a very long time to solve .

zh-CN: 现在其中的一些细菌确实携带了抗生素抗体遗传因子。
en-US: some of these infections are actually carrying antibiotic resistance genes now .

zh-CN: 这就使得治疗更加困难。
en-US: and that makes them even more difficult .

zh-CN: 这些传染源使得有害藻类大量繁殖。
en-US: these same infections create harmful algal blooms .

zh-CN: 繁殖会产生其他的化学物质。
en-US: those blooms are generating other kinds of chemicals .

zh-CN: 这是几种有毒物质的清单说明了这些有毒海藻的危害：贝毒、甲藻鱼毒、痢疾性贝毒——你不会想了解这种毒的——神经性贝毒、麻痹性贝毒。
en-US: this is just a simple list of some of the types of poisons that come out of these harmful algal blooms : shellfish poisoning , fish ciguatera , diarrhetic shellfish poisoning -- you don't want to know about that -- neurotoxic shellfish poisoning , paralytic shellfish poisoning .

zh-CN: 这些有害物质因为海藻大量繁殖而进入到我们的食物链中。
en-US: these are things that are getting into our food chain because of these blooms .

zh-CN: 丽塔·卡威尔成功的追寻到一个有趣的故事是关于人类感染霍乱的，他们不是被正常人传染而是被海上的一种桡足动物传染的。
en-US: rita calwell very famously traced a very interesting story of cholera into human communities , brought there , not by a normal human vector , but by a marine vector , this copepod .

zh-CN: 桡足动物是小甲壳动物。
en-US: copepods are small crustaceans .

zh-CN: 只有几分之一英寸长。
en-US: they're a tiny fraction of an inch long .

zh-CN: 弧菌会依附在它们细小的腿上然后使人类得病。
en-US: and they can carry on their little legs some of the cholera bacteria that then leads to human disease .

zh-CN: 这引发了霍乱病沿着港口传向整个世界并迫使人们注意到要努力不让船只成为向世界传播霍乱病的传染源。
en-US: that has sparked cholera epidemics in ports along the world and has led to increased concentration on trying to make sure shipping doesn't move these vectors of cholera around the world .

zh-CN: 我们该做点什么呢？
en-US: so what do you do ?

zh-CN: 我们主要的问题是生态系统运转遭到破坏金字塔食物链也运转不畅，食物链从底部开始就处于阻塞状态。
en-US: we have major problems in disrupted ecosystem flow that the pyramid may not be working so well , that the flow from the base up into it is being blocked and clogged .

zh-CN: 该怎么处理这种流通不畅的问题呢？
en-US: what do you do when you have this sort of disrupted flow ?

zh-CN: 其实有很多能做的事。
en-US: well , there's a bunch of things you could do .

zh-CN: 例如，可以叫水管工来修理。
en-US: you could call joe the plumber , for example .

zh-CN: 他就会进来并疏通管道。
en-US: and he could come in and fix the flow .

zh-CN: 但实际上，如果放眼世界就不光是希望解决我们能解决的问题，有些地方的问题已经解决了，有些地方的人们已经了解了这些问题并开始寻求解决办法。
en-US: but in fact , if you look around the world , not only are there hope spots for where we may be able to fix problems , there have been places where problems have been fixed , where people have come to grips with these issues and begun to turn them around .

zh-CN: 蒙特雷就是其中之一。
en-US: monterey is one of those .

zh-CN: 在开始的时候我展示了蒙特雷海岸生态系统已经被破坏的程度这是因为污染和罐头工厂还有随之而来的各种问题。
en-US: i started out showing how much we had distressed the monterey bay ecosystem with pollution and the canning industry and all of the attendant problems .

zh-CN: 这是1932年的照片。
en-US: in 1932 that's the picture .

zh-CN: 2009年的照片中已经有明显不同。
en-US: in 2009 the picture is dramatically different .

zh-CN: 罐头工厂迁走了，污染也减轻了。
en-US: the canneries are gone. the pollution has abated .

zh-CN: 但更有意义的是社区居民所需的是一个健全的生态系统。
en-US: but there's a greater sense here that what the individual communities need is working ecosystems .

zh-CN: 他们需要从下到上功能良好的金字塔食物链。
en-US: they need a functioning pyramid from the base all the way to the top .

zh-CN: 目前在蒙特雷这条食物链，在各方人士的努力之下，功能前所未有的健全150年来从未如此。
en-US: and that pyramid in monterey , right now , because of the efforts of a lot of different people , is functioning better than it's ever functioned for the last 150 years .

zh-CN: 这不是突然发生的。
en-US: it didn't happen accidentally .

zh-CN: 这是因为许多人付出了时间和精力并投入了先驱者的精神。
en-US: it happened because many people put their time and effort and their pioneering spirit into this .

zh-CN: 左边这位，朱丽娅·普拉特是我家乡小镇葛洛芙洋的镇长
en-US: on the left there , julia platt , the mayor of my little home town in pacific grove .

zh-CN: 她在74岁的时候当选镇长因为她做了一些保护海洋的事情。
en-US: at 74 years old , became mayor because something had to be done to protect the ocean .

zh-CN: 1931年，她设计了加州第一个基于社区的海洋保护区，紧挨着污染最重的罐头厂因为朱丽娅知道当罐头厂最终迁走之后，海洋需要一块地方来复原，换句话说海洋需要一块地方抛砖引玉。
en-US: in 1931 , she produced california's first community-based marine protected area , right next to the the biggest polluting cannery because julia knew that when the canneries eventually were gone , the ocean needed a place to grow from , that the ocean needed a place to spark a seed .

zh-CN: 她想要成为这先驱者。
en-US: and she wanted to provide that seed .

zh-CN: 其他人像大卫·帕卡德和朱莉·帕卡德，他们帮助筹建了蒙特雷湾水族馆以此让人们了解这片海洋和海洋生态系统的健康和当地的经济发展一样重要但经济发展却侵害了海洋生态。
en-US: other people david packard and julie packard , who were instrumental in producing the monterey bay aquarium to lock into people's notion that the ocean and the health of the ocean ecosystem were just as important to the economy of this area as eating the ecosystem would be .

zh-CN: 这种思想上的转变已经导致了巨大的变化，不仅改变了蒙特雷湾的命运还影响了世界上的其他地方。
en-US: that change in thinking has led to a dramatic shift , not only in the fortunes of monterey bay , but other places around the world .

zh-CN: 接下来，我希望让你们知道，我们正在尝试去做的事情是保护海洋金字塔食物链。
en-US: well , i want to leave you with the thought that , what we're really trying to do here is protect this ocean pyramid .

zh-CN: 而海洋食物链和我们的食物链紧密相连。
en-US: and that ocean pyramid connects to our own pyramid of life .

zh-CN: 这是个海洋星球，虽然我们认为自己是陆地生物。
en-US: it's an ocean planet , and we think of ourselves terrestrial species .

zh-CN: 但是海洋生物的食物链和我们陆地生物有着紧密的联系。
en-US: but the pyramid of life in the ocean and our own lives on land are intricately connected .

zh-CN: 只有让海洋健康我们才能确保自身的健康。
en-US: and it's only through having the ocean being healthy that we can remain healthy ourselves .

zh-CN: 十分感谢。
en-US: thank you very much .

zh-CN: ForrestNorth:任何合作的开始都起源于一段交谈
en-US: the beginning of any collaboration starts with a conversation .

zh-CN: 而我非常愿意和你们一同分享我们刚开始时的一些谈话
en-US: and i would like to share with you some of the bits of the conversation that we started with .

zh-CN: 我是在华盛顿州的一个小木屋里长大的拥有相当多的空闲时间
en-US: i grew up in a log cabin in washington state with too much time on my hands .

zh-CN: YvesBehar:而我则是在风景秀丽的瑞士
en-US: and in scenic switzerland for me .

zh-CN: ForrestNorth:一直以来我对清洁能源交通工具都充满了热情
en-US: i always had a passion for alternative vehicles .

zh-CN: 曾经有一次我驾驶陆地风帆穿越了内华达州的一个沙漠。
en-US: this is a land yacht racing across the desert in nevada .

zh-CN: YB：那结合了风帆和滑雪的技术
en-US: combination of windsurfing and skiing into this invention there .

zh-CN: FN：另外我还有一项非常危险的发明
en-US: and i also had an interest in dangerous inventions .

zh-CN: 这是一个十万伏特的泰斯拉变压器是我在自己的卧室里搞出来的对此，我老妈非常恼火
en-US: this is a 100,000-volt tesla coil that i built in my bedroom , much to the dismay of my mother .

zh-CN: YB：要是我妈也会恼火这确实是一个非常危险的年轻人的时尚
en-US: to the dismay of my mother , this is dangerous teenage fashion right there .

zh-CN: FN：我对清洁能源的热情终于落到了现实我曾经开着一辆太阳能车横穿了澳大利亚
en-US: and i brought this all together , this passion with alternative energy. and raced a solar car across australia .

zh-CN: 还有美国和日本
en-US: also the u.s. and japan .

zh-CN: YB：风能，太阳能，我们谈论了很多话题
en-US: so , wind power , solar power , we had a lot to talk about .

zh-CN: 太多让我们兴奋不已的话题
en-US: we had a lot that got us excited .

zh-CN: 于是，我们决定一起做一个独具一格的项目
en-US: so we decided to do a special project together .

zh-CN: 把工程学、设计学等都结合起来
en-US: to combine engineering and design and ...

zh-CN: 真的做一个全智能的产品出来，一个牛X的东西
en-US: really make a fully integrated product , something beautiful .

zh-CN: 然后就有了这个宝贝
en-US: and we made a baby .

zh-CN: 现在能请出我们的宝贝吗？
en-US: can you bring out our baby ?

zh-CN: 这位美女是全自动的
en-US: this baby is fully electric .

zh-CN: 每小时能达到150英里的速度
en-US: it goes 150 miles an hour .

zh-CN: 是其他普通电动摩托车速度的两倍
en-US: it's twice the range of any electric motorcycle .

zh-CN: 对于电动摩托车来说这确实是一个令人振奋的事情正是工业设计的完美结合
en-US: really the exciting thing about a motorcycle is just the beautiful integration of engineering and design .

zh-CN: 它有令人惊奇的用户体验
en-US: it's got an amazing user experience .

zh-CN: 跟YvesBehar合作真是太棒了
en-US: it was wonderful working with yves behar .

zh-CN: 他想出来了我们的名字和logo，我们是MissionMotors(该品牌名）
en-US: he came up with our name and logo. we're mission motors .

zh-CN: 尽管我们只有3分钟的时间
en-US: and we've only got three minutes .

zh-CN: 但是我们能够谈论它好几个小时
en-US: but we could talk about it for hours .

zh-CN: FN：谢谢TED，谢谢克里斯，邀请我们来到这里
en-US: thank you ted. and thank you chris , for having us .

zh-CN: 我在欧洲长大那时正好是二战时期我是7岁到10岁的光景
en-US: i grew up in europe , and world war ii caught me when i was between seven and 10 years old .

zh-CN: 我体会到身边的大人没有几个能够经受得起战争带给他们的创伤很少可以重建起一种正常的、舒心的满意的、快乐的生活因为他们的工作、家庭以及安全都因为战争而失去
en-US: and i realized how few of the grown-ups that i knew were able to withstand the tragedies that the war visited on them -- how few of them could even resemble a normal , contented , satisfied , happy life once their job , their home , their security was destroyed by the war .

zh-CN: 于是我开始对什么元素的注入可以丰富人们的生活这一话题发生兴趣
en-US: so i became interested in understanding what contributed to a life that was worth living .

zh-CN: 那是我还是孩子不过也开始读哲学的书并且尝试过艺术、宗教等各种我认为可以为我解开谜团的途径
en-US: and i tried , as a child , as a teenager , to read philosophy and to get involved in art and religion and many other ways that i could see as a possible answer to that question .

zh-CN: 最终则是意外的与心理学结了缘
en-US: and finally i ended up encountering psychology by chance .

zh-CN: 那次我去到了瑞士的一个滑雪胜地身上分文都没有我是去那玩的那时雪已消融我没钱去看电影但是我从报纸上看到说将会有一场演讲地点是苏黎世市中心一个我去过的地方他要讲的是飞碟
en-US: actually i was at a ski resort in switzerland without any money to actually enjoy myself , because the snow had melted and there was -- i didn't have money to go to a movie , but i found that on the -- i read in the newspapers that there was to be a presentation by someone in a place that i'd seen in the center of zurich , and it was about flying saucers he was going to talk .

zh-CN: 我就想既然不能去看电影但至少可以去听一下这个讲飞碟的演讲吧
en-US: and i thought , well , since i can't go to the movies , at least i will go for free to listen to flying saucers .

zh-CN: 那晚上的演讲非常有趣
en-US: and the man who talked at that evening lecture was very interesting .

zh-CN: 他没有讲绿色皮肤的外星人他讲到欧洲人的心灵如何因为二战而受到了创伤因而就以放飞碟来自娱他还讲到古代印度的曼荼罗也是在战后被人扔到天空以此来重新建立一种秩序
en-US: and it -- actually , instead of talking about little green men , he talked about how the psyche of the europeans had been traumatized by the war and now they're projecting flying saucers into the sky , kind of as a -- he talked about how the mandalas of ancient hindu religion were kind of projected into the sky as an attempt to regain some sense of order after the chaos of war .

zh-CN: 我对此很感兴趣
en-US: and this seemed very interesting to me .

zh-CN: 于是就开始读相关的书
en-US: and i started reading his books after that lecture .

zh-CN: 那人的名字是荣格而那时我还不知道这个名字
en-US: and that was carl jung , whose name or work i had no idea about .

zh-CN: 后来就到了美国学习心理学我开始探寻幸福之本源
en-US: then i came to this country to study psychology and i started trying to understand these roots of happiness .

zh-CN: 这是很多人都展示过的一个结果有很多个版本
en-US: this is a typical result that many people have presented , and there are many variations on it .

zh-CN: 而这一个则显示自1956年有调查记录以来有30%的美国受访公民说他们的生活非常快乐
en-US: but this , for instance , shows that about 30 percent of the people surveyed in the united states since 1956 say that their life is very happy .

zh-CN: 这一点几乎没有变
en-US: and that hasn't changed at all .

zh-CN: 但是同一时期的人均收入则增加了两倍以上接近三倍这一统计已经是把通货膨胀算进去了
en-US: whereas the personal income , on a scale that has been held constant to accommodate for inflation , has more than doubled , almost tripled , in that period .

zh-CN: 可是结果基本是一致的就是说到了温饱线之上1000美元之后的某个点收入的增加不会影响人们的幸福值
en-US: but you find essentially the same results , namely , that after a certain basic point which corresponds more or less to just a few 1,000 dollars above the minimum poverty level , increases in material well-being don't seem to affect how happy people are .

zh-CN: 而基本生活物资之匮乏则会导致不幸福但持续的物质财富之增长并不会带来更大的幸福
en-US: and , in fact , you can find that the lack of basic resources , material resources , contributes to unhappiness , but the increase in material resources do not increase happiness .

zh-CN: 所以当我发现这些东西与我自身的经历相吻合时我在后来的研究里就开始询问在正常的日常生活中我们怎么才会感到幸福
en-US: so my research has been focused more on -- after finding out these things that actually corresponded to my own experience , i tried to understand now , where in everyday life , in our normal experience , do we feel really happy .

zh-CN: 研究刚开始的时候我寻找那些有创意的人士首先是艺术家、科学家我尝试找到是什么让他们感觉自己的一生是值得的他们做的很多事情都不能带来荣誉和财富但那样的事情使得他们的人生充满意义
en-US: and to start that -- those studies about 40 years ago , i began to look at creative people -- first artists and scientists and so forth -- trying to understand what made them feel that it was worth essentially spending their life doing things for which many of them didn't expect either fame or fortune , but which made their life meaningful and worth doing .

zh-CN: 这是1970年代美国最出色的一位作曲家
en-US: this was one of the leading composers of american music back in the '70s .

zh-CN: 我跟他的对话记录长达40页
en-US: and the interview was 40 pages long .

zh-CN: 而这一段则是一个很好的总结是对他的发言的总结
en-US: but this little excerpt is a very good summary of what he was saying during the interview .

zh-CN: 它描绘出作曲家在写曲子时的感受
en-US: and it describes how he feels when composing is going well .

zh-CN: 他讲的时候也是一种狂喜的状态
en-US: and he says by describing it as an ecstatic state .

zh-CN: 而狂喜一词在希腊语里的意思是站在某个东西的边上
en-US: now ecstasy in greek meant simply to stand to the side of something .

zh-CN: 后来就成为一种心智状态的代名词用来形容非正常的行为
en-US: and then it became essentially an analogy for a mental state where you feel that you are not doing your ordinary everyday routines .

zh-CN: 换言之狂喜就是一种超越寻常的感觉
en-US: so ecstasy is essentially a stepping into an alternative reality .

zh-CN: 有趣的是当我们想起那些被公认为人类文明之巅峰的文明时不管是在中国、希腊或者是印度或玛雅、或埃及我们所听说的都是关于他们的狂喜的故事而不是他们日常生活的琐事
en-US: and it's interesting , if you think about it , how , when we think about the civilizations that we look up to as having been pinnacles of human achievement -- whether it's china , greece , hindu civilization , or the mayas , or egyptians -- what we know about them is really about their ecstasies , not about their everyday life .

zh-CN: 我们知道他们建了大型的殿堂人们可以去到那样的地方去感受不一样的现实
en-US: we know the temples they built so -- where people could come to experience a different reality .

zh-CN: 还有马戏团的故事斗兽场戏院这些都是文明之遗迹也是当时的人们经常光顾的地方他们去到那里去体验一种更加紧凑更具节奏的生活
en-US: we know about the circuses , the arenas , the theaters -- these are the remains of civilizations and they are the places that people went to experience life in a more concentrated , more ordered form .

zh-CN: 这个人不需要去到这样的地方这里这块地方就像一个古希腊的斗兽场也是一个狂欢之地
en-US: now , this man doesn't need to go to a place like this , which is also -- this place , this arena , which is built like a greek amphitheatre , is a place for ecstasy also .

zh-CN: 我们参与进去所体验到的与日常生活完全不一样
en-US: we are participating in a reality which is different from that of everyday life that we're used to .

zh-CN: 但这并不意味着我们必须去到那样的地方
en-US: but this man doesn't need to go to there .

zh-CN: 这位作曲家只需一张纸就能够把整个乐曲写下来与此同时他在脑海里想象一种从未有过的特殊的声音的组合
en-US: he needs just a piece of paper where he can put down little marks , and as he does that , he can imagine sounds that had not existed before in that particular combination .

zh-CN: 只要他开始真正要创作就像刚才珍妮弗的即兴演奏他就进入了一种新的现实进入狂喜
en-US: so once he gets to that point of beginning to create -- like jennifer did in her improvisation -- a new reality , that is a moment of ecstasy .

zh-CN: 那是不一样的现实
en-US: he enters that different reality .

zh-CN: 他说那是一种非常紧凑的体验他似乎也感觉不到自己的存在
en-US: now he says also that this is so intense an experience that it feels almost as if he didn't exist .

zh-CN: 这也许有点夸张
en-US: and that sounds like a kind of a romantic exaggeration .

zh-CN: 但事实上我们的神经系统是无法在一秒的时间里同时处理超过110比特的信息
en-US: but actually , our nervous system is incapable of processing more than about 110 bits of information per second .

zh-CN: 你在听我说话并且尝试去理解其中的意思这就相当于处理60比特的信息
en-US: and in order to hear me and understand what i'm saying , you need to process about 60 bits per second .

zh-CN: 所以说同时听到两个以上的人的会话是不可能的
en-US: that's why you can't hear more than two people .

zh-CN: 你不可能同时做到这一点
en-US: you can't understand more than two people talking to you .

zh-CN: 假如你真的是全身心的投入此间像这位作曲家那样去创造一种新的东西就不可能再有精力去感知他的身体在那一刻发生的变化
en-US: well , when you are really involved in this completely engaging process of creating something new , as this man does , he doesn't have enough attention left over to monitor how his body feels , or his problems at home .

zh-CN: 不知饥饿与劳累
en-US: he can't feel even that he's hungry or tired .

zh-CN: 似乎整个躯体都消失了在他的意识里不再有自己的存在他没有那么多精力事实上我们某个人都不可能做得到因为做那样的事情确实需要全副身心的投入他就不可能感知自己的存在了
en-US: his body disappears , his identity disappears from his consciousness , because he doesn't have enough attention , like none of us do , to really do well something that requires a lot of concentration and at the same time to feel that he exists .

zh-CN: 他的存在被暂时遗忘了
en-US: so existence is temporarily suspended .

zh-CN: 他自己也说他的手似乎能够不由自主的活动
en-US: and he says that his hand seems to be moving by itself .

zh-CN: 我也许对着自己的手看两个星期也不能看出有什么不一样的地方因为我不是作曲家
en-US: now , i could look at my hand for two weeks , and i wouldn't feel any awe or wonder , because i can't compose .

zh-CN: 这说明了什么？访谈当中还提到这样一个自动的、自发的过程只有可能发生在一个受过严格训练以及培养了良好的钢琴技艺的人身上
en-US: so what is that telling you here , but in other parts of the interview is that obviously this automatic , spontaneous process that he's describing can only happen to someone who is very well-trained and who has developed technique .

zh-CN: 在创造力研究这一领域有一个接近真理的说法是没有10年时间的积累是不可能产生出这类的奇迹的
en-US: and it has become a kind of a truism in the study of creativity that you can't be creating anything with less than 10 years of technical knowledge immersion in a particular field .

zh-CN: 不管是数学、音乐都需要这样漫长的时间来达到这个境界达到一种全新的升华
en-US: whether it's mathematics or music -- it takes that long to be able to begin to change something in a way that it's better than what was there before .

zh-CN: 而这样的事情一旦发生他就说音乐仿佛是流出来了。
en-US: now , when that happens , he says the music just flows out .

zh-CN: 而我所采访的这些人这是一个30年前的会议记录很多人将此称为“即兴的流动”这是我给过程起的名字是
en-US: and because all of these people i started interviewing -- this was an interview which is over 30 years old - - so many of the people described this as a spontaneous flow that i called this type of experience the " flow experience . "

zh-CN: 它正在不同的领域内发生
en-US: and it happens in different realms .

zh-CN: 比如有位诗人如此写到
en-US: for instance , a poet describes it in this form .

zh-CN: 这是我的一位学生他采访了美国最杰出的作家、诗人
en-US: this is by a student of mine who interviewed some of the leading writers and poets in the united states .

zh-CN: 同样也是一种狂喜的状态在那种状态下诗人们可以非常轻松的写出诗来
en-US: and it describes the same effortless , spontaneous feeling that you get when you enter into this ecstatic state .

zh-CN: 这位诗人则说那就有如打开了通往天际之窗这个跟爱因斯坦所说的关于相对论的设想非常相像那时的爱因斯坦也是在苦苦的思考为何那样的事情会发生
en-US: this poet describes it as opening a door that floats up in the sky -- very similar description to what albert einstein gave as to how he imagined the forces of relativity when he was struggling with trying to understand how it worked .

zh-CN: 在其他的领域也会发生这样的事情
en-US: but it happens in other activities .

zh-CN: 这是我的另一位学生她叫苏珊·杰克逊，来自澳洲她采访了世界上顶尖的运动健将
en-US: for instance , this is another student of mine , susan jackson from australia , who did work with some of the leading athletes in the world .

zh-CN: 这是关于一位奥林匹克滑冰运动员的的介绍也是同样的一段现象学的描述描绘的是一个人的内心活动
en-US: and you see here in this description of an olympic skater , the same essential description of the phenomenology of the inner state of the person .

zh-CN: 你也许会认为那样的事情要自然的发生是不可能的但只要当你将自己与音乐融为一体之时就发现那是可能的
en-US: you don't think it goes automatically if you merge yourself with the music , and so forth .

zh-CN: 我最近写了一本书，里面也提到这样的例子书名是《优良商业》我采访了一些公司的总裁同行们都认为那些人是非常成功的并且他们做企业非常讲道德、有社会责任
en-US: it happens also , actually , in the most recent book i wrote , called " good business , " where i interviewed some of the ceos who had been nominated by their peers as being both very successful and very ethical , very socially responsible .

zh-CN: 他们关于成功的定义是这样的既帮助他人的同时使自己乐在其中
en-US: you see that these people define success as something that helps others and at the same time makes you feel happy as you are working at it .

zh-CN: 这些成功并且富有社会责任的总裁也说到单单有其中一样是不足以令你成功的
en-US: and like all of these successful and responsible ceos say , you can't have just one of these things to be successful .

zh-CN: 假如你要的是有意义的工作、成功的工作安妮塔·罗迪克是其中一位受访的总裁
en-US: if you want a meaningful job and successful job -- anita roddick is another one of these ceos we interviewed .

zh-CN: 她创建了BodyShop，那是一个化妆品企业她自己则成为了天然化妆品之母
en-US: she is the founder of body shop , the cosmetic , kind of natural cosmetic king .

zh-CN: 这正是一种热情它源自一个人对最高价值的追求并且在工作中体会到一种“流动”
en-US: it's kind of a passion that comes from doing the best and having flow while you ' re working .

zh-CN: 这是井深大说过的一句话他那时手无分文，却创建了索尼他们那时甚至连产品也拿不出来可谓一无所有但是他们有一个理念
en-US: this is an interesting little quote from masaru ibuka , who was , at that time , starting out sony without any money , without a product -- they didn't have a product , they didn't have anything , but they had an idea .

zh-CN: 即他要创建一个工作环境使得工程师可以体验到技术创新带来的快乐同时也意识到自身对于社会的使命以最大的热情工作直到自己内心满意为止
en-US: and the idea he had was to establish a place of work where engineers can feel the joy of technological innovation , be aware of their mission to society and work to their heart's content .

zh-CN: 再也没有比这个更好的例子了“流动”就是这样走进公司的
en-US: i couldn't improve on this as a good example of how flow enters the workplace .

zh-CN: 而我们在做研究的时候我们与世界其他地区的研究员一起访问了8000人，他们有的是多米尼加的和尚失明的尼姑、喜马拉雅山攀登者、納瓦霍牧羊人他们都喜欢自己的工作
en-US: now , when we do studies , we have , with other colleagues around the world , done over 8,000 interviews of people -- from dominican monks , to blind nuns , to himalayan climbers , to navajo shepherds -- who enjoy their work .

zh-CN: 不管他们身处什么地方不管他们的教育背景如何只要存在以下的七个条件我们就能感受到“流动”的存在
en-US: and regardless of the culture , regardless of education or whatever , there are these seven conditions that seem to be there when a person is in flow .

zh-CN: 首先是精神的集中集中到一定程度就会走向狂喜清醒可以很清楚的知道自己下一刻该做什么因为你能够得到即时的反馈
en-US: there's this focus that once it becomes intense , leads to a sense of ecstasy , a sense of clarity , you know exactly what you want to do from one moment to the other , you get immediate feedback .

zh-CN: 你知道自己将要做的是可以做的尽管会遇到不少困难时间感也消失了你甚至忘却了自我似乎能感到自己属于某个更大的整体
en-US: you know that what you need to do is possible to do , even though difficult , and sense of time disappears , you forget yourself , you feel part of something larger .

zh-CN: 而一旦有了那样的征兆你做的事情本身也会变得有意义
en-US: and once those conditions are present , what you are doing becomes worth doing for its own sake .

zh-CN: 我们的研究得出的结果是人们的日常行为可以分为以下几大类
en-US: in our studies , we represent the everyday life of people in this simple scheme .

zh-CN: 我们可以非常准确的去测量我们会给参与测试的人发电子纸那样的纸每天会发出十次叫声它一叫你就马上说自己正在干什么你在哪里你正在想的是什么
en-US: and we can measure this very precisely , actually , because we give people electronic pagers that go off 10 times a day , and whenever they go off you say what you ' re doing , how you feel , where you are , what you ' re thinking about .

zh-CN: 我们测量的，一是人们在某一刻所面临的挑战的难度另一个是那一刻人们的技能熟练程度靠的是参与者自己说明
en-US: and two things that we measure is the amount of challenge people experience at that moment and the amount of skills that they feel they have at that moment .

zh-CN: 对于每一位参与者我们都能找到一个中间线即图表中的中线
en-US: so for each person we can establish an average , which is the center of the diagram .

zh-CN: 那是平均挑战难度以及技能熟练程度这个会与其他人的不一样
en-US: that would be your mean level of challenge and skill , which will be different from that of anybody else .

zh-CN: 同样在中间的地方会有一个固定的点
en-US: but you have a kind of a set point there which would be in the middle .

zh-CN: 假如我们能够知道这个固定的点在哪里我们就能大致预测出你何时会走进“流动”的状态那就是挑战大于平均值技能熟练程度也大于平均值的时候
en-US: if we know what that set point is , we can predict fairly accurately when you will be in flow , and it will be when your challenges are higher than average and skills are higher than average .

zh-CN: 你做的事情也许和其他人做的很不一样但是，对于每一个人，流动的出现通常都是在你做自己真正热爱的事情的时候才出现比如弹钢琴、跟好友在一起、甚或是工作假如你可以在工作中感受到“流动”的话
en-US: and you may be doing things very differently from other people , but for everyone that flow channel , that area there , will be when you are doing what you really like to do -- play the piano , probably , be with your best friend , perhaps work , if work is what provides flow for you .

zh-CN: 而其他的区域则变得相对更加消极
en-US: and then the other areas become less and less positive .

zh-CN: 觉醒还是好的，因为你在那一点上还是有较大的挑战
en-US: arousal is still good because you are over-challenged there .

zh-CN: 尽管你的技能熟悉程度不是很高但是可以很容易的进入“流动”只要增强一下技能就行了
en-US: your skills are not quite as high as they should be , but you can move into flow fairly easily by just developing a little more skill .

zh-CN: 觉醒是大多数人学习的地方他们在那样的区域就被迫走出舒适圈而后走进流动学会更高级的技能
en-US: so , arousal is the area where most people learn from , because that's where they're pushed beyond their comfort zone and that to enter -- going back to flow -- then they develop higher skills .

zh-CN: “控制”也是一个不错的地方因为你能感到舒服虽然不是很激动
en-US: control is also a good place to be , because there you feel comfortable , but not very excited .

zh-CN: 挑战也不是很强烈
en-US: it's not very challenging any more .

zh-CN: 假如要从那里走进“流动”就要增强挑战的程度
en-US: and if you want to enter flow from control , you have to increase the challenges .

zh-CN: 这两者是理想化的、相互补充的区域从这些地方可以很容易的进入“流动”
en-US: so those two are ideal and complementary areas from which flow is easy to go into .

zh-CN: 而挑战与技能的其他搭配，则会显得越来越消极。
en-US: the other combinations of challenge and skill become progressively less optimal .

zh-CN: 休息是好的，因为你还能感到舒适。
en-US: relaxation is fine -- you still feel ok .

zh-CN: 但厌倦就会产生反作用了而冷漠则会带来非常消极的后果因为你觉得自己根本就没有干出什么实际的事情你没有在使用好你的技能也没有什么挑战
en-US: boredom begins to be very aversive and apathy becomes very negative -- you don't feel that you ' re doing anything , you don't use your skills , there's no challenge .

zh-CN: 遗憾的是，很多人所经历的，大多是冷漠。
en-US: unfortunately , a lot of people's experience is in apathy .

zh-CN: 而导致这种情绪的元凶，就是看电视，其次则是蹲茅厕。
en-US: the largest single contributor to that experience is watching television , the next one is being in the bathroom , sitting .

zh-CN: 虽然有时候看电视，也有7%-8%的时间是处于“流动”，但那是在你挑选了一个你真正喜欢的频道的时候，你能够得到即时的反馈。
en-US: and then , even though sometimes watching television about seven to eight percent of the time is in flow , but that's when you choose a program you really want to watch and you get feedback from it .

zh-CN: 因此，我们要问的问题是，如何使得我们的生活更多的处于“流动”的状态。
en-US: so the question we are trying to address -- and i'm way over time -- is how to put more and more of everyday life in that flow channel .

zh-CN: 我们正在慢慢的解开其中的秘密。
en-US: and that is the kind of challenge that we're trying to understand .

zh-CN: 你们当中有人懂得如何去做，哪怕我不给你任何提示，可惜大多数人都不会。
en-US: and some of you obviously know how to do that spontaneously without any advice , but unfortunately a lot of people don't .

zh-CN: 而我们的任务之一，就是帮助那些人寻找到做事情的方法。
en-US: and that's what our mandate is in a way to do . ok .

zh-CN: 我希望可以帮助大家重新理解什么是慈善，以及慈善可以怎么做，还有是你们可以跟慈善发生什么关系。
en-US: i want to help you re-perceive what philanthropy is , what it could be , and what your relationship to it is .

zh-CN: 为了达到那样的目的，我希望可以给大家带来一个视界，一个想象中的未来，就如诗人SeamusHeaney所说的“人生中总会有那么一次人们期待已久的正义的浪潮会卷起，希望与历史也与之呼应。”
en-US: and in doing that , i want to offer you a vision , an imagined future , if you will , of how , as the poet seamus heaney has put it , " once in a lifetime the longed - for tidal wave of justice can rise up , and hope and history rhyme. "

zh-CN: 我想先是由这些词语的配对开始
en-US: i want to start with these word pairs here .

zh-CN: 我希望大家可以知道我们到底是站在那一边
en-US: we all know which side of these we'd like to be on .

zh-CN: 一百年前，当人们重新发明慈善的时候基金会的形式被发明出来了那时候的人们也不会想到他们是站在了错误的一边。
en-US: when philanthropy was reinvented a century ago , when the foundation form was actually invented , they didn't think of themsevles on the wrong side of these either .

zh-CN: 事实上，他们根本也不会想到那时候的慈善做法是非常封闭、保守反应迟钝规模小、并且常常规避风险的
en-US: in fact they would never have thought of themselves as closed and set in their ways , as slow to respond to new challenges , as small and risk-averse .

zh-CN: 但事实上那不是。在那个时代，我们的前辈事实上是在重新发明慈善。
en-US: and in fact they weren't . they were reinventing charity in those times .

zh-CN: 洛克菲勒称之为“仁慈的事业”。
en-US: what rockefeller called " the business of benevolence . "

zh-CN: 到了20世纪的末期，新一代的批评家以及改革家，就是以这样的方式来看待慈善的。
en-US: but by the end of the twentieth century , a new generation of critics and reformers had come to see philanthropy just this way .

zh-CN: 而当一个全球性的慈善事业，发展起来之后，——这恰恰是正在发生的事情，——我们需要的是重新评估老的法则，甚至是颠覆以往对慈善的假定。
en-US: the thing to watch for as a global philanthropy industry comes about , and that's exactly what is happening , is how the aspiration is to flip these old assumptions .

zh-CN: 要使得慈善成为一个可以长期延续的、开放的迅速发展、相互关联的体系。
en-US: for philanthropy to become open and big and fast and connected , in service of the long term .

zh-CN: 这样一种创业的精神，现在正是从各个方面展现出来。
en-US: this entrepreneurial energy is emerging from many quarters .

zh-CN: 很多新的领袖，像这里的很多人正在推进促使它的发展新的工具，比如我们在这里所看到的这些新的压力也同样起着推进作用
en-US: and it's driven and propelled forward by new leaders , like many of the people here , by new tools , like the ones we've seen here , by new pressures .

zh-CN: 我很久以前就在跟踪这一动态，并且参与其中。
en-US: i've been following this change for quite a while now , and participating in it .

zh-CN: 这是我们制作的最主要的公开报告
en-US: this report is our main public report .

zh-CN: 它所讲述的就是为何今天会成为跟100年前同样有历史意义的故事。
en-US: what it tells is the story of how today actually could be as historic as 100 years ago .

zh-CN: 我希望可以与大家分享一些最有趣的故事这些故事也许就发生在你们的身上
en-US: what i want to do is share some of the coolest things that are going on with you .

zh-CN: 需要指出的是，我不打算谈大的慈善这里很多人都已经讲过了那也是盖茨、索罗斯和Google在做的事情
en-US: and as i do that , i'm not going to dwell much on the very large philanthropy that everybody already knows about , the gates and the soros and the google .

zh-CN: 我今天想说的，是我们所有人的慈善
en-US: instead , what i want to do is talk about the philanthropy of all of us .

zh-CN: 或曰慈善的民主化。
en-US: the democratization of philanthropy .

zh-CN: 这也是普通人也能比历史上的人拥有更多力量的时代
en-US: this is a moment in history when the average person has more power than at any time .

zh-CN: 我想给大家看看五个方面的实验他们每一个都挑战着我们对于慈善的传统看法
en-US: what i'm going to do is look at five categories of experiments , each of which challenges an old assumption of philanthropy .

zh-CN: 首先是大规模协作，其代表就是维基百科
en-US: the first is mass collaboration , represented here by wikipedia .

zh-CN: 这也许真的会让你感到吃惊
en-US: now , this may surprise you .

zh-CN: 但你必须记住，慈善本来就是一种付出时间与精力的行为，而不是金钱
en-US: but remember , philanthropy is about giving of time and talent , not just money .

zh-CN: ClayShirky这位著名的网络记录者，就非常漂亮的记录了时代变化所带来的新契机写得非常好
en-US: clay shirky , that great chronicler of everything networked , has captured the assumption that this challenges in such a beautiful way .

zh-CN: 他说，我们生活的这个世界人们为了爱去做小事为赚钱去做大事
en-US: he said , " we have lived in this world where little things are done for love and big things for money .

zh-CN: 而现在，我们有维基百科
en-US: now we have wikipedia .

zh-CN: 突然，我们也可以因为喜爱而成就大事
en-US: suddenly big things can be done for love. "

zh-CN: 今年春天，保罗·霍肯出了一本新书
en-US: watch , this spring , for paul hawken's new book .

zh-CN: ——相信你们很多人都认识这位作家和企业家
en-US: author and entrepreneur many of you may know about .

zh-CN: 那本书的书名是《看不见的力量》
en-US: the book is called " blessed unrest. "

zh-CN: 书推出的时候，也推出了系列的基于维基的网站并且都带有WISER这个标志
en-US: and when it comes out , a series of wiki sites under the label wiser , are going to launch at the same time .

zh-CN: WISER的意思是全球社会与环境责任索引
en-US: wiser stands for world index for social and environmental responsibility .

zh-CN: 它的使命是记录这一保罗所称的人类历史上最规模大发展最为迅速的运动连结他们，为他们带来更大的力量
en-US: wiser sets out to document , link and empower what paul calls the largest movement and fastest growing movement in human history .

zh-CN: 整个人类作为一个有机体在协力迎对今天的挑战
en-US: humanity's collective immune response to today's threats .

zh-CN: 当然，并非上述所讲的这些大的追求都会轻易成功。
en-US: now , all of these big things for love experiments aren't going to take off .

zh-CN: 但是，那些最终走向成功的项目必将成为人类历史上规模最大、最为开放发展最为迅速以及联系最为广泛的慈善行动
en-US: but the ones that do are going to be the biggest , the most open , the fastest , the most connected form of philanthropy in human history .

zh-CN: 第二类是在线的慈善行动
en-US: second category is online philanthropy marketplaces .

zh-CN: 这就如慈善领域的eBay以及Amazon
en-US: this is , of course , to philanthropy what ebay and amazon are to commerce .

zh-CN: 或者你可以将其看作是点对点的慈善
en-US: think of it as peer-to-peer philanthropy .

zh-CN: 这又挑战了我们的另外一个设想即慈善仅仅是富人才干得起的事情
en-US: and this challenges yet another assumption , which is that organized philanthropy is only for the very wealthy .

zh-CN: 假如你还不知道，请看看DonorsChoose这个网站吧
en-US: take a look , if you haven't , at donorschoose .

zh-CN: OmidyarNetwork为这个慈善网站投入了大量的钱。
en-US: omidyar network has made a big investment in donorschoose .
